text.p: Oil and gas producer Petroleum Securities Australia Ltd (Petsec) reported a doubling of its total petroleum reserves in the year to June 30 and a three-fold increase in production.

In posting a doubling of annual net profit after abnormal and extraordinary items to A$6.8 million, Petsec said net proven oil reserves leapt to 10.2 million barrels from 6.9 million barrels in 1994/95.
Net gas reserves jumped to 61.9 billion cubic feet (bcf) from 20.3 bcf, it added.
The total net reserves doubled to 123.2 bcf equivalent from 61.6 bcf equivalent, Petsec said.
The annual accounts also showed production had surged to a total 21.6 billion bcf equivalent from 7.2 bcf equivalent.

"The sharp increase in the company's petroleum reserves followed a significantly expanded and successful exploration and development programme in the Gulf of Mexico ... during the past year," Petsec managing director Terry Fern said in a statement.
Petsec drilled 10 wells in the year, all of them productive, he said. "This is the second successive year that the company has doubled its proved reserves," he added.
Sales revenue, after royalties, from the Gulf of Mexico rose to A$67.6 million, up A$44.4 million on 1994/95, Petsec said.
It said it planned to spend about US$70 million on exploration and development in 1996/97, including the drilling of at least 12 wells in the Gulf of Mexico region in the year.
Before an extraordinary loss arising from the removal of Climax Mining Ltd from Petsec's consolidated accounts, net profit was A$13.6 million, up from A$3.3 million in 1994/95.
